title-group.article-title: Toward Perpetual War? The Stakes and Limits of Schmitt's Critique of Kant's Cosmopolitanism

contrib.aff: Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique (UMR 8547, Archives Husserl) and École Normale Supérieure, Paris

bio.p: JEAN-CLAUDE MONOD is a research fellow at the Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique (UMR 8547, Archives Husserl) and teaches at the École Normale Supérieure (Paris). He specializes in post-Hegelian German philosophy and political philosophy, looking in particular at the intersection of politics, religion, and modernity. He has publishedLa Querelle de la sécularisation, de Hegel à Blumenberg(Vrin, 2002),Penser l'ennemi, affronter l'exception. Réflexions critiques sur l'actualité de Carl Schmitt(La Découverte, 2007),Hans Blumenberg(Belin, « Voix allemandes », 2007),Sécularisation et laïcité(PUF, 2007).

RON ESTES is a Ph.D. candidate in the Department of Comparative Literature at the State University of New York at Buffalo, where he is finishing a dissertation on Nostalgia and the Uncanny in the Nineteenth-Century British and American Gothic Novel. He has translated essays by Jean-Luc Nancy, Eva Geulen, Gerard Wajcman and Willy Apollon. He currently resides in Seville, Spain.

ref.mixed-citation: We would have to evoke here the anthropological and theological presuppositions of these two visions (Schmitt's and Kant's) of peace and of law. Even before he had discovered the Pauline or pseudo-Pauline motif of the “katechon,” that is, he who “holds back” the end of times, Schmitt seems to have made the words of St. Paul his own: “he will come like a thief in the night, when people are saying ‘peace and security.’” Any attempt to establish a definitive peace on earth is thus seen by Schmitt as an attempt to realize paradise on earth by human means, which amounts to a negation of original sin—an enterprise worthy of the Antichrist. This (“pessimistic”) understanding of the Christian vision of history goes against that of Kant, yet he, contrary to what Schmitt claims regarding “progressive” thinkers, does not subscribe to a purely “optimistic” anthropology of an essentially “good” mankind that it would be necessary to “liberate” from all constraint, that is, the state and the law. Such a “promise” would situate itself, for Kant, beyond law and the political. Kant instead developed a mixed understanding of mankind according to which he is possessed both of a “penchant for evil” as well as of a “disposition for good”: hence the image of the “crooked wood,” of a soaring toward the heights ceaselessly opposed, in appearance, by a sinking back to the bottom, and of nonlinear progress. The fact that Kant maintains the possibility of war as a “goad” to freedom, and the fact that he expects progress toward peace to be derived from the law and not only from morality, are so many translations of this mixed anthropology.
